 The most detailed description of the dinner conversation which has
been found was written by Harry Dexter White, who accompanied
Mforgeuthau to Quebec. No source on the meeting (including White's
memorandum itself) states that White was present, and it seems prob-
able that White was summarizing what Morgenthau had told him, or
told others in his presence, in the period between September 13 and the
date on which White's memorandum was prepared. Following is the
text of the memorandum, which bears the date "9/25/44" at the end
(presumably the date of typing):
 "Thouch shipping was supposed to have been the subject for dis-
cussion the subject of shipping was not mentioned the entire evening
except briefly when the question was raised as to the advisability of
taking away all of Germany s shipping.
 'Mhq discussion uickly turned to Germany. Churchill (apparently
without reference to anything said previously) said something along-
thle line of 'What are mv Cabinet members doing discussing plans for
Germany without first discussing them with me? I intend to get into
the matter myself.'
 "The President said he had asked Secretary Morgenthau to come
tip for the purpose of discussing Germany and that he (Morgen-
tlhan) was to talk to Cherwell the following day.
 "Churchill asked: 'Why don't we discuss Germaiiy now?' The
President then asked the Secretary to explain the program lie had in
muid for Germany. The Secretary described that part of the Treasury
prol')osal dealing with the Ruhr,4 Churchill indicated that he was
strongly opposed to such a program. HIe said that all that was neces-
sary was to eliminate the production of armament. To do what the
Treasury suggested was 'unnatural, unchristian and unnecessary.'
Curohfll: didn't believe that it would be very much of an aid to the
United Kingdom even if the United Kingdom did get the steel busi-
ness t~hat formerly went to Germany.
 "Adminral Land, on the other hand, wholly supported Secretary
AMorgenthau's proposal, thumping vigorously on the table to emphasize
his r niark. Admiral Land told the Secretary after the dinner that
the President had been talking with him more or less along those lines
for a long time but this was the first time that he (Admiral Land)
had a chance to say what he felt. He had long been waiting for the
opportunitu^y and, encouraged by the Secretary's statement, he had
vigorously expressed himself.
 "When the question arose about taking away German ships,
Churchill was opposed. Admiral Land said, 'Why not? It is no more
cruel to take away ships than their steel plants.'
